title: 104_s949
content: The "George Washington Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $5 coins with specific specifications. The coins will contain 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy, weigh 8.359 grams, and have a diameter of 0.850 inches. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Gold for minting will be obtained by the Secretary from other provisions of law. The design of the coins minted under the George Washington Commemorative Coin Act shall be emblematic of George Washington, with specific inscriptions and designations. The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with relevant organizations and committees. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility. The Secretary may begin issuing coins on May 1, 1999, but minting authority ends on November 1, 1999. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. A surcharge of $35 per coin will be included in all sales. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to Mount Vernon Ladies' Association for endowment and education on George Washington. The Comptroller General can audit the Association's expenditures. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the government for minting coins. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
